testcases.title: Access admin panel without authorization
testcases.description: The application allows access to administrative endpoints without validating the user’s authorization level. Requests made by low-privileged users are processed successfully without server-side permission checks.
impact: Modification or exposure of sensitive system data
remediation: Validate user roles before granting access to admin endpoints
Restrict administrative functionality to privileged users only

testcases.title: Force browsing to restricted URLs
testcases.description: Restricted URLs can be accessed directly by entering them in the browser without proper authorization checks. The application does not enforce access control on these endpoints.
remediation: Apply authorization checks to all restricted URLs
Deny direct access to sensitive endpoints

testcases.title: Access another user’s data via IDOR
testcases.description: By modifying object identifiers in requests, users can access data belonging to other users. The application does not validate ownership of the requested objects.
remediation: Validate object ownership on the server
Enforce authorization checks for each request

testcases.title: Download another user’s document via ID manipulation
testcases.description: File identifiers can be altered in download requests to retrieve documents belonging to other users. No ownership validation is performed before serving the file.
remediation: Enforce ownership checks on file access
Restrict access to files based on user context
Log and monitor unauthorized download attempts

testcases.title: Privilege escalation via role tampering
testcases.description: Users can manipulate role-related attributes in requests to elevate their privileges. The server accepts these changes without proper validation.
remediation: Protect role attributes from client-side modification
Enforce role validation strictly on the server

testcases.title: Reuse admin session token as normal user
testcases.description: Session tokens associated with administrative users can be reused by normal users. The application does not properly bind session tokens to user roles.
remediation: Bind session tokens to specific user roles

testcases.title: Invoke restricted backend function directly
testcases.description: Backend functions can be invoked directly without authorization checks. The application does not enforce access control at the function level.
remediation: Apply authorization checks at function level
Restrict backend functionality based on roles

testcases.title: Access internal API endpoint without permission
testcases.description: Internal API endpoints are accessible without proper authentication or authorization. Requests are processed without validating user permissions.
remediation: Enforce authorization checks for internal endpoints
Limit access to trusted services only

testcases.title: Bypass workflow restrictions
testcases.description: Users can bypass intended business workflows by directly invoking backend endpoints. Workflow state validation is not enforced on the server.
remediation: Validate workflow states on the server
Restrict endpoint access based on workflow context

testcases.title: Access deactivated account resources
testcases.description: Resources belonging to deactivated accounts remain accessible through direct requests. Access is not properly revoked when accounts are disabled.
impact: Unauthorized access to inactive account resources
Failure to enforce account lifecycle controls
remediation: Revoke access immediately upon account deactivation
Validate account status on every request

testcases.title: Missing Content-Security-Policy header
testcases.description: The application does not implement a Content-Security-Policy HTTP header. This allows the browser to load and execute untrusted scripts, increasing the risk of client-side attacks.
impact: Increased risk of cross-site scripting attacks
Execution of untrusted scripts in user browsers
remediation: Define and enforce a strict Content-Security-Policy
Restrict script sources to trusted domains
Regularly review and update security headers

testcases.title: Missing X-Frame-Options header
testcases.description: The application does not include the X-Frame-Options HTTP header, allowing it to be embedded within iframes on external websites.
impact: Unauthorized user interaction through UI redressing
remediation: Set X-Frame-Options to DENY or SAMEORIGIN

testcases.title: Overly permissive CORS policy allows any origin
testcases.description: The server allows cross-origin requests from any domain without restriction. This misconfiguration enables untrusted websites to interact with sensitive APIs.
impact: Unauthorized access to sensitive API data
remediation: Restrict allowed origins in CORS configuration

testcases.title: CORS allows credentials with wildcard origin
testcases.description: The CORS configuration allows credentials to be sent while using a wildcard origin. This combination violates security best practices and enables credential abuse.
remediation: Disable wildcard origins when allowing credentials

testcases.title: Login using default administrator credentials
testcases.description: The application allows login using default administrator credentials that were never changed after deployment.
remediation: Force password changes on first login

testcases.title: Default database credentials exposed
testcases.description: Backend services use default database credentials, allowing attackers to authenticate directly to the database.
remediation: Use unique strong passwords for services
Store credentials securely using secrets management

testcases.title: Application running in debug mode in production
testcases.description: The application is deployed with debug mode enabled in a production environment, exposing internal application details.

testcases.title: Verbose error messages exposed to users
testcases.description: The application displays detailed error messages to end users, revealing internal logic and configuration details.
remediation: Log detailed errors securely on the server
Prevent debug information from reaching users

testcases.title: Unused administrative service exposed
testcases.description: Unused administrative services are exposed and accessible from the network without proper restrictions.

testcases.title: Exposed management endpoints
testcases.description: Management or monitoring endpoints are exposed without adequate authentication or network restrictions.
remediation: Limit exposure to trusted administrators only

testcases.title: Application uses outdated third-party JavaScript library
testcases.description: The application relies on an outdated third-party JavaScript library with publicly known security vulnerabilities. These vulnerabilities are exploitable due to lack of timely updates.
remediation: Monitor vulnerability databases for affected components

testcases.title: Backend framework version contains known security flaws
testcases.description: The backend framework version used by the application contains publicly disclosed vulnerabilities. Attackers can exploit these flaws due to delayed patching.
impact: Remote code execution or privilege escalation
remediation: Upgrade backend frameworks to secure versions

testcases.title: Critical dependency has not been patched
testcases.description: A critical application dependency remains unpatched despite the availability of security updates. This exposes the application to known attack vectors.

testcases.title: Use of deprecated cryptographic dependency
testcases.description: The application uses deprecated cryptographic dependencies that are no longer maintained or supported. These components may contain unresolved security weaknesses.
remediation: Replace deprecated dependencies with secure alternatives

testcases.title: Malicious package installed via dependency confusion
testcases.description: The application resolves dependencies from public repositories before private ones, allowing attackers to introduce malicious packages through dependency confusion.
remediation: Configure package managers to prioritize private repositories

testcases.title: Private package name collision with public repository
testcases.description: Private package names collide with packages hosted on public repositories. This allows attackers to publish malicious packages with identical names.
impact: Loss of trust in build pipeline

testcases.title: Dependencies installed from untrusted third-party repository
testcases.description: The application installs dependencies from unverified third-party repositories. These repositories may host compromised or malicious packages.
impact: Increased risk of supply chain attacks
remediation: Restrict dependency sources to trusted repositories

testcases.title: Unsigned dependency packages used in production
testcases.description: Dependencies are used without validating their digital signatures. This increases the risk of using tampered or malicious packages.
impact: Execution of modified or malicious code

testcases.title: Third-party API SDK contains known vulnerabilities
testcases.description: The third-party API SDK integrated into the application contains publicly disclosed vulnerabilities. These flaws can be exploited by attackers.
impact: Data leakage through vulnerable SDK functions

testcases.title: Build pipeline uses outdated build tools
testcases.description: Build tools used in the CI/CD pipeline are outdated and contain known vulnerabilities. Attackers may target the build process to inject malicious artifacts.
impact: Injection of malicious code into releases

testcases.title: Use of deprecated encryption algorithm (MD5)
testcases.description: The application uses the deprecated MD5 hashing algorithm to protect sensitive data. MD5 is cryptographically broken and vulnerable to collision and brute-force attacks.
impact: Sensitive data can be recovered from cracked hashes
Compromise of authentication or stored credentials
remediation: Replace MD5 with secure hashing algorithms such as SHA-256 or bcrypt

testcases.title: Use of weak symmetric encryption (DES)
testcases.description: Sensitive data is encrypted using the DES algorithm, which is considered insecure due to its short key length and known cryptographic weaknesses.
impact: Encrypted data can be decrypted by attackers
remediation: Replace DES with strong encryption algorithms such as AES-256
Ensure encryption configurations follow best practices

testcases.title: Hardcoded encryption key found in source code
testcases.description: Encryption keys are hardcoded directly in the application source code. Anyone with access to the codebase can retrieve and misuse these keys.
remediation: Remove hardcoded keys from source code
Store keys securely using environment variables or a KMS
Rotate all exposed or compromised keys

testcases.title: API secret key hardcoded in configuration file
testcases.description: API secret keys are embedded in configuration files stored in the repository. These files may be accessible to unauthorized users.
remediation: Rotate and revoke exposed API keys immediately

testcases.title: Cryptographic keys are not rotated periodically
testcases.description: Cryptographic keys are used for long periods without rotation. Compromised keys remain valid and usable indefinitely.
remediation: Define key lifecycles and expiration periods

testcases.title: Improper storage of encryption keys
testcases.description: Encryption keys are stored in plaintext on the server or within application files. This allows attackers to retrieve keys after gaining access.
remediation: Store keys using HSMs or cloud-based KMS solutions

testcases.title: Sensitive data transmitted without encryption
testcases.description: Sensitive data is transmitted over the network without using TLS encryption. Attackers can intercept traffic through man-in-the-middle attacks.
remediation: Use TLS with secure cipher suites
Redirect all HTTP traffic to HTTPS

testcases.title: Sensitive data stored without encryption at rest
testcases.description: Sensitive user data is stored in plaintext within the database. If the database is compromised, all stored data is exposed.
remediation: Use strong encryption algorithms for storage
Limit database access to authorized components

testcases.title: Use of insecure random number generator for cryptography
testcases.description: Cryptographic operations rely on predictable or insecure random number generators. This weakens the strength of cryptographic keys and tokens.
remediation: Use cryptographically secure random number generators
Review randomness sources used in security functions

testcases.title: Shared encryption keys used across environments
testcases.description: The same encryption keys are reused across development, staging, and production environments. A compromise in one environment affects all others.
impact: Increased blast radius of security incidents
remediation: Use separate keys for each environment
Restrict key access based on environment

testcases.title: SQL injection via login form
testcases.description: User input submitted through the login form is concatenated directly into SQL queries. The application fails to validate or parameterize input, allowing attackers to manipulate query logic.
impact: Unauthorized access to sensitive database records
remediation: Use parameterized queries or prepared statements
Validate and sanitize all user inputs

testcases.title: Blind SQL injection in search functionality
testcases.description: The search endpoint is vulnerable to blind SQL injection, where attackers infer database behavior through response timing or error patterns.
remediation: Use prepared statements for database queries

testcases.title: Stored XSS via user profile field
testcases.description: User-supplied input is stored in the application and rendered to other users without proper output encoding, allowing persistent script execution.
impact: Execution of malicious scripts in user browsers

testcases.title: Reflected XSS in error message
testcases.description: The application reflects user-controlled input in error messages without sanitization, enabling script execution via crafted URLs.
remediation: Escape user input before rendering responses
Avoid reflecting raw user input in errors

testcases.title: OS command injection via file name parameter
testcases.description: User input provided as a file name is passed directly to system-level commands. The application does not restrict or validate command execution.
impact: Remote code execution on the server
remediation: Use safe APIs instead of shell execution

testcases.title: Ping command injection through diagnostic feature
testcases.description: Diagnostic functionality allows users to execute system commands. Attackers can inject arbitrary OS commands through crafted input.

testcases.title: LDAP injection in authentication query
testcases.description: User input is directly embedded into LDAP authentication queries without sanitization, allowing attackers to alter query logic.

testcases.title: LDAP filter manipulation via search field
testcases.description: Attackers can manipulate LDAP search filters by injecting special characters into user input.

testcases.title: NoSQL injection in MongoDB query
testcases.description: User input is directly embedded into NoSQL database queries, allowing attackers to manipulate query operators.

testcases.title: JSON-based NoSQL injection in API request
testcases.description: The API accepts JSON input that allows injection of NoSQL query operators, leading to unauthorized data access.
remediation: Disable operator-based queries from user input

testcases.title: No threat modeling performed during application design
testcases.description: The application was designed without performing formal threat modeling exercises. As a result, potential attack vectors and abuse scenarios were not identified early.
impact: Higher likelihood of exploitable design flaws
remediation: Perform threat modeling during the design phase
Identify assets, threats, and trust boundaries
Update threat models as the application evolves

testcases.title: Abuse cases not identified during design phase
testcases.description: Potential abuse scenarios were not identified or documented during the design phase. This allows attackers to exploit overlooked functionality.
remediation: Identify abuse and misuse cases during design

testcases.title: Bypass of payment workflow steps
testcases.description: Attackers can manipulate application logic to skip mandatory payment steps. The workflow does not enforce proper state validation.
impact: Financial loss due to unpaid transactions
Loss of trust in application integrity
remediation: Enforce workflow integrity on the server
Validate workflow state before processing actions

testcases.title: Unlimited coupon reuse due to flawed business logic
testcases.description: Coupons can be reused multiple times due to missing usage validation logic. The system does not enforce redemption limits.
remediation: Track coupon usage per user or transaction

testcases.title: Workflow bypass using direct API calls
testcases.description: Users can directly invoke API endpoints to bypass intended application workflows. No server-side validation of workflow state is performed.
remediation: Validate workflow state on every API call
Restrict endpoint access based on workflow context

testcases.title: Order cancellation allowed after shipment
testcases.description: The system allows order cancellation even after shipment due to flawed workflow design and missing state checks.
remediation: Restrict actions based on workflow state
Validate order status before processing changes

testcases.title: Unlimited requests allowed on authentication endpoint
testcases.description: Authentication endpoints do not enforce rate limiting. Attackers can send unlimited requests to brute-force credentials.
impact: Brute force and credential stuffing attacks
remediation: Apply rate limiting on authentication endpoints
Monitor and alert on abnormal request rates

testcases.title: API allows unlimited requests per client
testcases.description: APIs do not enforce request rate limits per user or IP address, allowing excessive and abusive usage.
remediation: Protect APIs with abuse detection mechanisms

testcases.title: Negative quantity allowed during checkout
testcases.description: Users can submit negative values for item quantity during checkout. The application does not enforce logical input constraints.

testcases.title: No security review of new feature design
testcases.description: New features are introduced without conducting security design reviews. This results in preventable security weaknesses being deployed.
remediation: Integrate security reviews into design processes
Perform threat modeling for new features
Involve security teams early in development

testcases.title: Weak password policy allows short passwords
testcases.description: The application allows users to set passwords shorter than recommended security standards. Short and simple passwords significantly reduce resistance to brute force and guessing attacks.
impact: Successful brute force or password guessing attacks
remediation: Require complexity including numbers and symbols

testcases.title: Password reuse allowed across multiple accounts
testcases.description: The application allows users to reuse previously used passwords. This weakens security when passwords are exposed through breaches.

testcases.title: Credential stuffing attack not detected
testcases.description: The application does not detect or block credential stuffing attempts. Attackers can use leaked username-password combinations at scale.
remediation: Implement anomaly detection for login attempts
Apply rate limiting and IP throttling

testcases.title: No protection against automated login attempts
testcases.description: Automated login attempts are not challenged or blocked. Attackers can rapidly test large credential lists.

testcases.title: Unlimited login attempts allowed
testcases.description: The login endpoint allows unlimited authentication attempts without restriction. Attackers can repeatedly guess credentials.
remediation: Apply rate limiting to login endpoints

testcases.title: No delay between failed authentication attempts
testcases.description: The application does not introduce delays after failed login attempts, allowing attackers to rapidly test passwords.

testcases.title: Session remains valid after logout
testcases.description: User sessions remain active even after logout due to improper session invalidation. Attackers can reuse existing session tokens.

testcases.title: Predictable session identifiers used
testcases.description: Session identifiers are predictable and insufficiently random, allowing attackers to guess valid session tokens.
remediation: Use cryptographically secure random session IDs
Protect session cookies with secure flags

testcases.title: Multi-factor authentication not enforced
testcases.description: The application does not enforce multi-factor authentication for sensitive actions or privileged access.
impact: Single-factor compromise leads to account takeover

testcases.title: MFA optional for administrative users
testcases.description: Administrative users are not required to use multi-factor authentication, leaving privileged accounts protected by single-factor authentication.
impact: High risk of administrative account takeover
remediation: Enforce mandatory MFA for all administrators
Apply MFA to privileged roles by default

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Unsafe deserialization of untrusted data
testcases.description: The application deserializes untrusted data without validating its structure or origin. This allows attackers to manipulate serialized objects to execute arbitrary code.
impact: Remote code execution on the server
Loss of data integrity and confidentiality
remediation: Use safe data formats such as JSON
Validate and whitelist allowed object types

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Object injection via serialized payload
testcases.description: Serialized objects are accepted from untrusted sources without integrity or authenticity validation. Attackers can inject malicious payloads.
remediation: Reject serialized input from untrusted sources

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Updates applied without integrity verification
testcases.description: Software updates are applied without verifying cryptographic integrity or authenticity. Malicious updates can be injected into the update process.

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Unsigned update packages accepted
testcases.description: The update mechanism does not enforce digital signature validation on update packages.
impact: Loss of trust in update process

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Tampered update package not detected
testcases.description: Modified update packages bypass integrity checks due to weak or missing validation mechanisms.

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Integrity verification skipped during deployment
testcases.description: Deployment pipelines skip integrity verification steps for application artifacts, allowing compromised builds to be deployed.
remediation: Enforce integrity verification in CI/CD pipelines

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Third-party updates pulled from untrusted source
testcases.description: Updates are fetched from unverified third-party repositories without trust validation.

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Deserialization of untrusted session objects
testcases.description: Session data is deserialized without integrity validation, allowing attackers to manipulate session objects.
remediation: Use signed and encrypted session data

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Update mechanism lacks rollback protection
testcases.description: The update mechanism does not provide rollback protection for failed or malicious updates.

testcases.owasp_category: A08:2025 - Software and Data Integrity Failures
testcases.title: Integrity validation disabled in production
testcases.description: Integrity validation mechanisms are disabled in production environments for performance reasons.
remediation: Enable integrity validation in all environments
Optimize integrity checks rather than disabling them

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Authentication failures are not logged
testcases.description: Failed authentication attempts are not recorded in application logs. This prevents detection of brute force and credential stuffing attacks.
remediation: Include user, IP address, and timestamp

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Privilege escalation events not logged
testcases.description: Changes to user roles and privileges are not logged. Unauthorized privilege escalation can occur without detection.
remediation: Log all role and permission changes
Capture before and after privilege states

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Log injection via user input
testcases.description: Unsanitized user input is written directly to log files. Attackers can inject misleading or malicious log entries.

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Forged log entries using newline injection
testcases.description: Attackers inject newline characters to forge fake log entries, hiding malicious actions.

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: No alerts for repeated failed logins
testcases.description: Repeated authentication failures do not trigger alerts. Ongoing attacks remain unnoticed by security teams.
remediation: Enable alerts for repeated login failures

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Critical security events do not generate alerts
testcases.description: High-risk security events such as privilege escalation or configuration changes do not trigger alerts.
remediation: Configure alerts for critical security events
Ensure alerts reach security teams promptly

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Security incidents do not trigger response workflows
testcases.description: Security alerts are not integrated with incident response workflows. Manual intervention is required to respond.
remediation: Integrate alerting with incident response systems

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Security team not notified of critical incidents
testcases.description: Critical security alerts are not escalated to the security team in a timely manner.
remediation: Define escalation paths for critical alerts

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Sensitive data access not logged
testcases.description: Access to sensitive resources is not logged or audited, making it difficult to trace unauthorized access.
remediation: Enable audit logging for sensitive data
Log user identity and access context

testcases.owasp_category: A09:2025 - Security Logging and Alerting Failures
testcases.title: Log retention period insufficient
testcases.description: Logs are deleted too quickly, preventing effective forensic analysis after incidents.

testcases.title: Stack trace exposed in application error response
testcases.description: The application displays detailed stack traces to end users when errors occur. These stack traces expose internal code structure, class names, and execution flow.
remediation: Disable stack trace display in production
Show generic error messages to users

testcases.title: Unhandled exception reveals framework internals
testcases.description: Unhandled exceptions expose framework versions, file paths, and internal components through detailed error responses.
remediation: Suppress technical error details in responses
Log exception details securely on the server

testcases.title: Verbose error messages shown to end users
testcases.description: Verbose error pages reveal internal method names, variables, and execution logic during application failures.
remediation: Disable verbose error output in production

testcases.title: Database error messages exposed to users
testcases.description: Database errors are returned directly to users, revealing query details and schema information.
remediation: Log database errors securely on the backend

testcases.title: Generic server errors reveal backend logic
testcases.description: Server error responses leak backend processing logic and application behavior details.

testcases.title: HTTP 500 errors expose internal service details
testcases.description: Internal service names and configuration details are exposed through HTTP 500 error responses.
impact: Improved attacker understanding of system layout

testcases.title: Error handling differs between environments
testcases.description: Production environments return more verbose error information than expected due to inconsistent configuration.

testcases.title: Application exposes exception messages in API responses
testcases.description: Raw exception messages are returned directly in API responses without sanitization.

testcases.title: Stack trace written to client-side logs
testcases.description: Stack traces are exposed in client-accessible logs, revealing internal call flows and logic.
remediation: Remove stack traces from client-side logs

testcases.title: Error debug mode enabled in production
testcases.description: Debug mode is enabled in production, exposing full error details and stack traces to users.
